text:
Rate limit suggestions needed.

I’m setting up a new sync of data from Attentive (marketing texts) to HubSpot for when new messages are sent. This can routinely result in tens of thousands of webhook events from Attentive within a very short time frame, so I need a way to capture those webhook events and then process them without hitting HubSpot’s API rate limits.

My first attempt that has run into rate limit issues was: AWS API Gateway → AWS Lambda Function. Each function invocation needed to hit the Search API and then update the matching contact record(s).
hey.  did you get this working?
i would check that folderPath value

How to determine if contact is opted-in to a subscription using the API?

We are trying to use the API to determine if a contact is Opted-in to a subscription or not. The v3 api version doesn’t seem to have the opt-in information, only if they are subscribed or not, which isn’t all the data. If GDPR is not enabled, then contacts don’t need to explicitly opt-in to a subscription and show as “subscribed” even if not opted-in. We need to know the difference, where do we get the opt-in data for a contact using the api?

hello, team!

which endpoint should I use in the api query to find a list of all deals by company id?
@here looking for out of the box MLS sync to HubSpot and YGL (you got listing integrations to HubSpot -options? thanks
Does anyone has experience considering PHP, GuzzleHttp and the HubSpot API? :slightly_smiling_face:

Hey guys,

My goal is to pull tasks under a specific queue and the associated company. From what I understand, I have to use the Search API to filter the queues I need and for me to pull the associated company, I have to create a separate GET request to list all tasks with their associated company. Is it possible to just do this all in one call or it has to be separate calls?
Hi guys, do you know where I can get the `Job Title` property of a contact using api?
So with the api setup the `properties` parameter and set it equal to `jobtitle` and whatever else you need
Thank you! It turns out it was using a _very_ old version of the PHP Library that wasn't updated for support to Bearer tokens.
I feel like those SDKs are always out of date
Yeah, especially when dealing with Composer on WordPress where there's no "simple" way to stay up to day :disappointed:
